As an AI language model, I do not have personal access to all up-to-date information, however, based on research conducted as of 2021, here are some statistics on racial disparities in the criminal justice system in the United States:

- African Americans are incarcerated in state prisons at a rate that is 5.1 times higher than that of whites.
- African Americans are arrested at a rate 2.8 times higher than that of whites.
- Hispanic Americans are three times more likely to be incarcerated than whites.
- Black Americans make up only 13% of the U.S. population but constitute 28% of all arrests and 40% of all inmates in state and federal prisons.
- Police are more likely to use force against Black suspects than white suspects.
- Sentencing disparities exist between Black and white individuals for similar offenses, with Black individuals receiving longer and harsher sentences.
- Black defendants are 30% more likely to be sentenced to jail time than white defendants for the same crimes.

These statistics indicate that racial disparities exist at every stage of the criminal justice system, from policing to sentencing.
